channel.title: [ C# ] RuneC - Scriptable Macro
channel.description:
I've been working on this project for 3 days out of sheer boredom, and am surprised at how far I've got. Basically, RuneC is a form of XML markup parsed using C# to simulate user input, and preform basic programming functions. It doesn't do a lot right now, but so far I have a few basic features fully working for this semi-language. -Printing messages to the standard output. -Moving the mouse to a specified x,y coordinate set. -Sending keyboard strokes to the currently focused window. -Pausing execution for the specified amount of milliseconds. -Variables. No types, but would be possible to add in the future. Right now, I'm working on if statements, and loops. Here is an example program that would output "Hello World!" [code] <program name="Untitled1" date="8/9/2007 8:41:43 PM" author="Owner"> <start /> <print>Hello World!</print> <end /> </program> [/code] Here is one that sends the value of the variable "message" to the currently focused window. [code] <program name="Untitled1" date="8/9/2007 8:41:43 PM" author="Owner"> <start /> <var name="message">Hello,from SendKeys!</var> <sendKeys msg="_message" /> <end /> </program> [/code] That example would send "Hello,from SendKeys!" as if typed from the keyboard. XML Tag list:
<program name=" {Program name} " date=" { Date program was created } " author=" { Username of the program creator } "> //Program info, always the very first element. </program> //End of the program, always the last element <start /> //Starting point for all code execution, always the second element <end /> //Ending point for all code execution, always the second last element <var name=" { Variable name } "> { Variable value } </var> //Initializes a new variable with the specified name and value. The variable is always accessed using the _ prefix, to differentiate a variable from a string. <sleep length=" { Time to pause in milliseconds } " /> //Pauses program execution for the specified amount of milliseconds <print> { Value to print } </print> //Prints the specified value to the standard output stream. <moveMouse x=" { X screen coordinate } " y=" { Y screen coordinate } " /> //moves the mouse to the specified screen coordinates. <sendKeys msg=" { Value to send } " /> //Sends the specified value to the currently focused application as if typed from the keyboard.
Notes: This isn't just an idea, all of this actually WORKS. Script files are saved at compile time as programName.rcs. Hoping to incorporate syntax highlighting along with many other standard IDE features into the built in editor. I'm not hoping to replace SCAR or anything, I'm making this because I have nothing better to do. RuneC is written in Visual C# 2005, using Visual Studio 2005 Express C# Edition. Source code may, or may not be released. How many people here know C# anyway...
Here is a picture of the editor, which has the compiler built in. It's quite bare at the moment, but will be improved upon.
[img]http://xs218.xs.to/xs218/07320/02.PNG[/img]
If you have any comments, please post. Or, if you'd just like to flame the crap out of me for making something so utterly useless, please feel free to do so.

item.title: [ C# ] RuneC - Scriptable Macro
item.dc:creator: @bakatool bakatool
item.description:
@bakatool wrote:

<script name="ifSTATEMENTS">

<var pi="3.14"/>
<var test="3.14"/>

	<MainProc>
		<if>pi == test</if>
			<print>It equals!</print>
		<elseif>pi != test</elseif>
			<print>It doesn't equal</print>
		<else/>
			<print>anything else !!</print>
		<endif/>
	</MainProc>       
</script>
<script name="SwitchStatements">
<var pi="3.14"/>
	<MainProc>
		<Switch pi>
		<case "1234"/>
			<print>1234</print>
		<case "777"/>
			<print>777</print>
		<case "stringtest"/>
			<print>its the stringtest!</print>
		<default/>
			<print>else here</print>
		</Switch>
	</MainProc>       
</script>

something i was just tackling with notepad… its not a real langauge just making it seem kinda easier to control.

with the use of basic HTML
blah

and bottleneck endings

Read full topic

item.title: [ C# ] RuneC - Scriptable Macro
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“bakatool, post:16, topic:132477”][code]
<xsl:for-each select="//Claim">
<xsl:if test=“file_date[not(. = @previous_date)]”> do something </xsl:if>

<tr>
	<xsl:apply-templates select="."/>
</tr>

</xsl:for-each>
[/code]

googled nicer xml format you should use maybe.[/quote]

That’s not a nicer xml format… that’s just XML stylesheets used for display purposes. It is actually allows basic scripting in an XML environment. It doesn’t look any nicer.

Read full topic

item.title: [ C# ] RuneC - Scriptable Macro
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

Updated the UI: http://xs218.xs.to/xs218/07320/02.PNG
As for porting to Java, Yikes. Java only allows integers in switch statements, so I would have to use a massive IF ELSE block to determine the name of the element when parsing. Java also has extremely lousy XML support. If I this does gain some popularity, I could always compile it in Mono to make it cross platform.
As for imports, yes, in a normal programming language you would do that. But I’ll do what ever the hell I want ;p

Read full topic

item.title: [ C# ] RuneC - Scriptable Macro
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Don’t variables have the underscore in front? If so, why does ‘if’ have the underscore in front and why doesn’t lol1 or lol2 have an underscore?

Variables have an underscore prefix when they are referenced, not when they are initialized. The _ isn’t actually part of the name, just a means to tell the compiler that it is a variable name, not a value. The reason if statements are prefixed, is that C# wouldn’t allow me to make a boolean named “if”, so I just prefixed it. In PHP, _ represents super globals, like $_GET and $_POST, while __ is used in things like __construct() which is the constructor method for a class. I guess I just copied that ;p

Read full topic

item.title: [ C# ] RuneC - Scriptable Macro
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

I have now got if statements working, so this:

<program name="Untitled1" date="8/9/2007 8:41:43 PM" author="Owner">
<start />
<var name="lol1">Hello</var>
<var name="lol2">Hello</var>
<_if condition="_lol1 == _lol2">
<print>O kewl, lol1 is the same as lol2...</print>
</_if>
<print>Done with the if statement...</print>
<end />
</program>

Would output “O kewl, lol1 is the same as lol2…” and “Done with the if statement…”

I am now extremely confused about my own code, and have a greater respect for the programmers who create programming languages. Next up is else statements and for loops ;s Eeeek

Read full topic
